questions.text: What is the most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young adults?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

 

SEQUELAE OF TRAUMATIC SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Most commonly it is subcoracoid type.
  • Other complications include:
    • Muscle, ligament or tendon rupture
    • Nerve or blood vessel damage around the joint
    • Shoulder instability

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frozen shoulder. Following dislocation, the shoulder shows some degree of limited motion owing to pain or apprehension for some time, which usually spontaneously recovers. However, some patients experience continuous stiffness after dislocation. This may lead to frozen shoulder if not mobilized early.

 

Option C. Normal shoulder healing and movements. The healing after the shoulder dislocation takes around 12-16 weeks. The movements are started slowly under the rehabilitation process.

 

Option D. Subscapular tendinitis. It is a rare complication of shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sequealae of the shoulder dislocation is the recurrence of the shoulder dislocation due to instability of the shoulder joint tissues.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has come with history of lower back pain and stiffness since 3 months. His ESR and CRP levels are raised. He has mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion is 3 cms. History of red eye is also there. The most likely diagnosis from amongst the following would be:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females.
    • Age of onset is between 15-25 years.
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
  • Etiology:
    • HLA B27 positive in more than 90 % cases
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • Bamboo spine (bony ankyloses)
    • Squaring of vertebrae
    • Inter-spinous ligament calcification: dagger sign
    • Facet calcification of joints + inter spinous ligament Trolley Track Sign
    • Sclerosed vertebral edges: romanus sign

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal. Increased marker of bone formation (e.g. S. alkaline phosphatase and S. osteocalcin). Increased markers of bone resorption. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Option B. Healed TB. The remineralization of the vertebral body, sharpening of disc margins, reduction of pre-/paravertebral shadows, and osseous/fibro-osseous fusion are signs of healing on X-rays but are unreliable. The remineralization can be appreciated after 2-3 months of ATT. Complete resolution of pre-/paravertebral collections, marrow edema of vertebra, and its replacement by fat/calcification on contrast MRI are observed with healing of spine TB. 

 

 

Serial radiographs showing progression of bony healing and complete resolution of cold abscess

 

Option C. DISH. Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spondyloarthropathy, also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis. It is a non-inflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses. The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankyloses occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected. In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine. The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine. Morning stiffness is also noticed in around 2/3rd of patients. Increased incidence of dysphagia is also reported in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of lower back pain and stiffness since months, raised levels of ESR and CRP, mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion, with history of red eye are suggestive of presence of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A patient of rheumatic heart disease who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field vision loss for the past 1 week. What is the probable cause of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO)

 

A patient with rheumatic heart disease is at an increased risk of thromboembolic events, which can affect the retinal vessels. The key features presented are a history of superior field vision loss over the past week, which suggests a gradual onset typical of venous occlusion rather than arterial occlusion.

 

Key Features of BRVO:

 

  • Gradual onset: BRVO often presents with gradual vision changes, which is consistent with the patient's history of vision loss over one week.
  • Superior field vision loss: Indicates that the inferior retinal quadrant is affected, as retinal involvement typically causes a visual field defect in the opposite quadrant.
  • Associated with thromboembolic phenomena: Patients with rheumatic heart disease have a higher risk of thromboembolic events, leading to BRVO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO): BRAO typically presents with a sudden onset of vision loss due to an acute blockage in the retinal artery. It is less common and would present immediately rather than over a week.

 

Option B. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): CRAO causes a sudden, painless, and profound loss of vision, not a gradual superior field vision loss.

 

Option D. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)

 

CRVO generally leads to a more severe, diffuse loss of vision, not limited to a specific field. It also typically presents with sudden vision loss rather than the gradual progression described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRVO is the most probable cause of superior field vision loss in a patient with rheumatic heart disease due to its association with thromboembolic events and gradual onset of symptoms.

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Identify the condition and the instrument:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

 

RULE OF IMMOBILISATION

 

  • Immobilise one joint above and 1 joint below the main target
  • Femur fracture: Fixation at hip joint and knee joint
  • Tibia fracture: Fixation at knee joint and ankle joint
  • Periarticular Knee fracture: Fixation at hip joint and ankle joint
  • Peri- and intra-articular fractures about the knee are frequently managed with joint-spanning external fixation before definitive treatment.
  • With a systematic approach, a near-anatomic reduction with respect to length, alignment, and rotation can be obtained.

 

KNEE SPANNING EXTERNAL FIXATOR

 

  • A joint-bridging external fixator is fixed to the femur and the tibia while the fracture zone is left virtually untouched (it is bridged).
  • Provisional reduction is achieved with distraction.
  • When external fixation is used to bridge the knee joint, it is always only for temporary fixation. Prolonged immobilization will lead to difficulties with knee mobility.
  • It is rapidly applied without need for intraoperative x-rays and can be adjusted later.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tibia fracture, Ilizarov fixator. The most stable external fixation for distal tibial fractures is usually composed by:

 

  • One fully circular ring with tensioned wires attached to the distal tibial articular segment
  • Two proximal fully circular rings to provide stable anchorage for the distal ring
  • An extension for the foot and ankle, and particularly for intraarticular fractures
  • 3-4 connecting rods between each ring

 

The proximal rings can be anchored with Schanz screws or tensioned wires. Wires are usually used in cancellous bone. Wires attached to a circular ring are typically tensioned at 100 to 130 kg-force.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

A spanning external fixator is used for stabilization of open and closed fractures, mainly intraarticular fractures of the lower extremity, around the knee and ankle joints.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased response to analgesia

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
    • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: Capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
    • Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
    • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.

 

Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: Below is an image of an MRCP scan. Which of the following options is the most probable diagnosis?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choledocholithiasis

 

The provided MRCP image displays several circular areas with decreased filling within the common bile duct, suggesting the presence of choledocholithiasis.

 

  • Most choledocholithiasis patients presents with obstructive jaundice and biliary colic.
  • Suspecting CBD stones - MRCP (IOC for CBD stone and Klastkin tumor)
  • IOC for small biliary calculi - Endoscopic (ultrasound (EUS)

 

Treatment of CBD stone

 

  • It is usually a slipped stone from GB into CBD (secondary CBD stone)
  • Primary CBD stones - rare, occur due infection of bile duct → seen in low socio economic status → worms infestation → brown pigment stones (due to production of glucoronidase)
  • ERCP – in cases of confirmed CBD stone - diagnostic and therapeutic

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholecystitis: This condition involves inflammation of the gallbladder, typically caused by gallstones blocking the ducts leading to the gallbladder, but not directly visualized as filling defects in the CBD on MRCP.

 

Option C. Pancreatic duct stricture: A stricture would be seen as a narrowing in the pancreatic duct rather than as filling defects in the bile ducts.

 

Option D. Malignancy: While malignancies can cause biliary obstruction, they usually present as irregular or mass-like obstructions within the bile ducts or surrounding tissues rather than discrete, round filling defects typical of stones.

 

Treatment of CBD Stone:

 

  • Secondary CBD stones are usually stones that have slipped from the gallbladder into the CBD. Treatment typically involves ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography), which is both diagnostic and therapeutic.
  • Primary CBD stones are less common and often associated with chronic infections of the bile duct in areas of low socioeconomic status, leading to brown pigment stones due to the action of bacterial glucuronidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choledocholithiasis is diagnosed primarily through imaging like MRCP, which reveals stones within the common bile duct as distinct circular filling defects. This condition is a significant cause of biliary obstruction and requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as severe biliary colic and obstructive jaundice.

choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve involved in this test: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

SPECIAL TESTS FOR MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign / Ochsner’s Clasping / Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. Special tests for ulnar nerve injury are:

 

  • Froment’s sign:
    • Test: The patient is asked to make a strong pinch between the thumb and index finger and grip a flat object such as a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the patient’s hands.
    • Interpretation: There is weakness of the adductor pollicis innervated by the ulnar nerve which would keep the IP joint relatively straight; instead, the FPL muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve is substituted for the AP and will cause the IP joint to go into a hyperflexed position.

 

 

  • Wartenberg’s sign:
    • Test: The patient’s places wrist in neutral and forearm in full pronation and is instructed to perform full extension of all the fingers. Once digits are extended, patient is asked to fully abduct and then adduct all fingers.
    • Interpretation: A positive sign is indicated with the observation of abduction of the 5th digit, with the inability to adduct the 5th finger when extended.

 

 

  • Egawa’s sign:
    • Test: The patient flexes the middle digit & then alternately deviates the finger radially & ulnarly.
    • Interpretation: If the patient is unable to do this Egawa’s sign, the interossei are affected.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Check strength of Biceps Brachii, Corocobrachialis and Brachialis muscles. Check sensation on lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The test image shown in the question is the Pen Test, which is done to diagnose median nerve injury.

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rheumatoid arthritis

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
      • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    1. Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    2. Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint, upper cervical spine
    3. Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
      • Usually, DIP is not involved. It is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
      • Lumbar spine is spared.
      • Others: The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children. Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heberden's nodes on pre-existing osteoarthritis. Heberden’s nad Bouchard’s nodes are firm swellings over the superolateral and dorsal aspects of DIP and PIP joints respectively. Lateral view of the x-ray of the hand reveals large exostoses arising from the proximal ends of the distal phalanges in the attachment of extensor and flexor tendons. They may begin as small, round, fluctuant, tender mass, a little to one side of the dorsum of the joint.

 

 

 

Option C. Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints. Tenosynovitis is quite common, but it is generally not a striking or isolated clinical complaint. The most common sites are the extensor tendon sheaths on the dorsum of the hand, the extensor sheaths over the dorsum of the foot, and those of the posterior tibial tendon and the peroneus longus and brevis tendons. If tenosynovitis is very prominent, Blau syndrome should be considered. Triggering or loss of extension of the fingers may result from a stenosing synovitis of the flexor tendon sheaths.

 

 

Option D. Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome. CRPS is characterized by a chronic neurological disorder involving upper or lower limbs after any type of injury or surgery. In some cases, it occurs spontaneously. Sensory and autonomic disturbances are the main features of this syndrome (allodynia or hyperalgesia, edema, changes in skin blood flow or abnormal sudomotor activity) and are disproportionate to the starting event. The underlying mechanism is still unknown. Multiple mechanisms considered to play a role in the generation and maintenance of CRPS includes biofeedback from autonomic nervous system, alterations of central nervous system, neurogenic inflammation and immunological mechanisms. There is no specific diagnostic test for CRPS. History, clinical examination, symptoms and signs of the patient are the main aspects to be considered for a correct diagnosis. CRPS does not have a pathognomonic sign. The key symptom is prolonged pain that may be constant and disproportionate to the initial injury. The characteristics of the pain are continuous, spontaneous or episodic. Patients frequently described this symptom as burning. The distal part of the limb is the most common area and the typical clinical manifestations are red skin, pain, and swelling. Symptoms may change over time and vary from patient to patient. Over time the injured limb can became pale, cold and in addition muscle spasm and tightening can appear. This condition is often irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image and the symptoms in a female of pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand, morning stiffness with problem in squatting is clinical for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

Androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium (1, 2 and 3) are responsible for non-scarring alopecia. On the other hand, frontal fibrosing alopecia falls under the category of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

 

  1. Alopecia areata 
    • It is an autoimmune condition that causes patchy hair loss.
    • The hair follicles are not destroyed and can regrow hair if the underlying inflammation is treated, thus it is considered non-scarring.
  2. Telogen effluvium 
    • It is a form of temporary hair loss that typically occurs after stress, a shock, or a traumatic event.
    • The hair loss is diffuse and does not involve scarring of the scalp.
  3. Androgenic alopecia
    • It is also known as male or female pattern baldness, is characterized by a progressive thinning of the hair in a typical pattern.
    • The condition is non-scarring as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner and shorter hairs but are not destroyed.
  4. FRONTAL FIBROSING ALOPECIA
    • Type of Hair Loss: Scarring alopecia primarily affecting the frontal hairline and eyebrows.
    • Predominantly Affects: Postmenopausal women.
    • Symptoms: Progressive hairline recession, eyebrow loss, and sometimes body hair loss.
    • Clinical Features:
      • Frontal Hairline Recession: Gradual and symmetrical.
      • Eyebrow Thinning: Outer third of eyebrows commonly affected.

 

 

  • Perifollicular Erythema: Redness around hair follicles.
  • Potential Causes: Autoimmune or hormonal factors may play a role.
  • Treatment:
    • Medical Approaches: Topical or systemic corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Cosmetic Solutions: Wigs, eyebrow makeup, tattoos.
  • Prognosis: Hair loss is often permanent; early intervention may slow progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia, which allows for the possibility of hair regrowth, includes alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is associated with scarring alopecia.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 32.24, 32.39-40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.7, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20, 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

questions.text: A 30-year-man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Lesion with giant cells and mononuclear cells in skeletally mature patient, GCT is the best answer.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

choices.text: Movement at the fracture site

questions.text: Which of the following factors increases callus formation? (AIIMS 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Movement at the fracture site

 

Explanation:
 

Movement at the fracture site, particularly micro movements, enhances callus formation. This is because slight movements stimulate the biological processes necessary for bone healing, including the proliferation of blood vessels and the development of new bone tissue. These micro movements encourage the formation of a callus, which is an essential part of the fracture healing process.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rigid immobilization: While immobilization is crucial to prevent displacement of the fracture, it also limits movement at the fracture site, which can delay callus formation by preventing the necessary biological stimulus.

 

Option C. Compression plating: This method provides rigid stabilization to the fracture site, reducing movement and thereby typically not promoting significant callus formation. Compression plating is more associated with primary bone healing without visible callus formation.

 

Option D. Intraosseous nailing: Like compression plating, intraosseous nailing stabilizes the fracture internally, limiting micro movements. This method is effective for fracture stabilization but does not significantly contribute to the formation of a callus due to the reduced movement.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Understand that micro movements at a fracture site enhance callus formation.

 

Recognize that rigid stabilization methods reduce callus formation by limiting movement.

 

Identify the impact of different fracture management techniques on bone healing.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codman’s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal 1/3rd

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Salient features: 

    • It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 

    • Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 

    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. 

    • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.

  • Most common location:              

    • Adults and adolescents: Middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%). 

    • Children: Distal pole avulsion type fracture.

  • Pathogenesis of AVN:

    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 

    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

    • Thus, the proximal third of the scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis (AVN) due to its precarious retrograde blood supply. 

    • Fracture in the waist (middle third) can disrupt this blood flow to the proximal fragment, leading to AVN.

  • Diagnosis: 

    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.

    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.

    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.

    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.

  • Treatment:

    • Nondisplaced, Stable Scaphoid Fractures: Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast.

    • Displaced, Unstable Scaphoid Fractures: Headless Screw (Herbert) is used

    • Complication: Non-union > Avascular Necrosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal 1/3rd. Distal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid is a well vascularized area, so fracture to this part is often undisplaced or minimally displaced, thus they heal faster with conservative management. This portion of scaphoid is fractured in 10% of cases. AVN of this part occurs in 1% cases. 

 

Option B. Middle 1/3rd. Middle 1/3rd or the waist of scaphoid is most commonly fractures, accounting for 70% of cases. But the chances of AVN at this portion are around 20%. 

 

Option D. Scaphoid tubercle. Avulsion fracture of scaphoid tubercle are rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid have less chances of fracture (20%) but have higher chances of AVN (40%).

choices.text: Ascending aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Superior vena-caval syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-menopausal female came with persistent back ache, not responding to conservative treatment. She has a history of heavy weight lifting 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking and starts radiating down her legs within 100m range of walking, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs. Most probable diagnosis is? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lumbar canal stenosis

 

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

 

  • Lumbar spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal, compressing the nerves travelling through the lower back into the legs.
  • While it may affect younger patients, due to developmental causes, it is more often a degenerative condition that affects people who are typically age 60 and older.
  • Narrowing of the spinal canal usually occurs slowly, over many years or decades.
  • Degenerative spondylosis is a significant etiology of lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • The discs become less spongy with aging, resulting in loss of disc height, and may cause bulging of the hardened disc into the spinal canal.
  • Bone spurs may also occur and ligaments may thicken.
  • All of these can contribute to narrowing of the central canal and may or may not produce symptoms.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis is another cause of lumbar spinal stenosis. When degenerative changes of the spine occur, the pars interarticularis can be fractured, and the resulting instability can lead to forward translation of the vertebra.  Sufficient anterior slippage of one vertebra on the next vertebral segment can narrow the spinal canal, leading to stenosis.
  • When the lateral recess and neural foramen are stenosed, symptoms of lumbar radiculopathy may also present.
  • Classification (anatomic):
    • Central stenosis: caused by hypertrophied ligamentaum flavum anteriorly and bulging disc posteriorly with consequent thecal sac compression
    • Lateral recess stenosis: due to facet joint arthropathy with overgrowth of the superior articular facet and osteophyte formation. This results in compression of the descending nerve roots.
    • Foraminal stenosis: due to loss of disc height, foraminal disc protrusion, or osteophyte formation with resultant compression of the exiting nerve root.
    • Extraforaminal stenosis: due to far lateral disc herniation again with resultant exiting nerve root compression 
  • Symptoms may be due to inflammation, compression of the nerve(s) or both.
  • Such symptoms may include:
    • Pain, weakness or numbness in the legs, calves or buttocks, exacerbated by prolonged ambulation, standing, and with lumbar extension, and is relieved by forward flexion and rest.
    • Neurogenic claudication is an important feature. Symptoms are bilateral, but usually asymmetric. Low back pain, numbness, and tingling are present.
    • Cramping in the calves with walking, requiring frequent short rests to walk a distance
    • Pain radiating into one or both thighs and legs, similar to the lay term “sciatica”
    • In rare cases, loss of motor functioning of the legs, loss of normal bowel or bladder function
    • Pain may improve with bending forward, sitting or lying down.
    • Walking upstairs being easier than walking downstairs, as the back is forward flexed with stairs climbing.
    • If patients present with new-onset bowel or bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, bilateral lower extremity weakness, and/or increased lower extremity, the patient may have developed cauda equina or conus medullaris syndromes. 
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis and degenerative scoliosis are two conditions that may be associated with lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis (slippage of one vertebra over another) is caused by osteoarthritis of the facet joints. Most commonly, it involves the L4 slipping over the L5 vertebra. It is usually treated with the same non-surgical (“conservative”) and surgical methods as lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Investigations:
    • MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the modality of choice for lumbar spinal stenosis, and CT myelography is an option when MRI is contraindicated.
    • Anteroposterior spinal canal diameters of less than 10 mm are also frequently used for the diagnosis of lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Treatment:
    • Management for lumbar spinal stenosis aims at reducing symptoms and improving functional status. 
    • Conservative treatment is the first-line treatment for this condition. 
    • Conservative treatment options include physical therapy, oral anti-inflammatory medications, and epidural steroid injections.
    • The most frequently performed surgical procedure is a laminectomy (Wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression). This is usually indicated in cases of ongoing pain despite conservative measures for 3-6 months and where there is progressive neurologic deterioration e.g. motor weakness, bowel and/or bladder dysfunction.
    • Laminectomy with fusion (wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression with instrumented fusion) is indicated when further stability is required, which is done in patients with concurrent segmental instability e.g. spondylolisthesis (degenerative or isthmic) or degenerative scoliosis.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Vertebral osteoporotic compression fracture. These are very common fragility fractures of the spine that affect up to 50% of people over 80 years old. The patient complains of pain localized to area of fracture. There is focal tenderness or pain with deep palpation of spinous process. Radiographs will show loss of anterior, middle, or posterior vertebral height by 20% or at least 4mm. Treatment is usually non-operative. If the fracture is less than five days old, calcitonin can be used for four weeks to decrease pain. Bisphosphonates can be given to prevent future risk of fragility fractures. Some patients may benefit from an extension orthosis. Surgical options may include vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty, surgical decompression and stabilization.

 

 

Option B. PIVD. A herniated disc in the spine is a condition during which a nucleus pulposus is displaced from intervertebral space. It is a common cause of back pain. Herniated disc pain often presents with burning sensation, and may radiate into the lower extremity. Furthermore, in more severe cases, there can be associated with weakness or sensation changes. The disc prolapse can be very painful. Within a few weeks, most cases heal. In many instances, it does not cause that patient any pain. They are often seen on MRI of asymptomatic patients. The initial treatment should be conservative, unless a patient has severe neurological compromise. Surgery is usually the last resort. Physical therapy is the key for most patients.

 

 

Option D. Isthmic spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis occurs when there is an anterior translation or “slippage” of one vertebral body relative to its caudal vertebral body. In most cases, symptoms associated with spondylolisthesis are chronic.  The primary symptom of chronic spondylolisthesis is back pain, with or without leg pain. Isthmic spondylolisthesis refers to a defect in the pars interarticularis that results in anterior subluxation over time, most commonly at L5-S1 followed by L4-5. The resulting anterior subluxation can produce back pain, central canal stenosis, and lateral recess or foraminal stenosis. The most common etiology for isthmic spondylolisthesis is instability of unilateral or bilateral pars interarticularis. The most common symptom of presentation is low back pain, which may be mechanical in nature, depressed deep tendon reflexes, positive straight leg signs, and diminished sensations. Isthmic spondylolisthesis with low back pain should initially be managed conservatively. Surgical treatment options consist of decompression of the neural elements alone versus decompression with internal fixation for bony fusion to prevent further subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A back pain that worsens on walking and radiates down the legs within 100m of walking, and that does not occur on climbing up the stairs, is suggestive of lumbar canal stenosis where the pain relieves on forward bending the trunk, as in climbing the stairs.

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: A 75-year-old female had a fall and had intertrochanteric fracture. This is due to:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteoporosis

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
    • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae (Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia)

 

Note: Intertrochanteric hip fractures are the most commonly occurring fractures in the elderly osteoporotic population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis. This disease is commonly seen in children. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis, leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant (congenital) osteopetrosis clinically presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Endobones (os in os or bone within bone appearance) and rugger jersey spine are seen on radiographs. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone, which leads to cortical widening and deformity. The diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization (Radiologically seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion). 2nd phase of active bone formation and resorption replaces normal lamellar bone with structurally weak woven bone that bend, bow and fracture easily. In 3rd sclerotic (burnt out) phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. It affects men (> 50 years) more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity.

 

 

Blade of grass

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: Match the following named fractures with the bones involved:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

1. March fracture:

  • Fatigue/stress fracture of the neck of 2nd and 3rd metatarsals.
  • More common in neck of 2nd metatarsal than 3rd metatarsal.

 

 

2. Bennett’s fracture:

  • Intra-articular fracture dislocation of base of 1st metacarpal.
  • Shaft is laterally dislocated by the unopposed pull of the abductor pollicis longus.
  • The medial projection of the thumb metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches, remains in place.

 

 

3. Jones fracture:

  • Avulsion fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal at the metaphysio-diaphyseal junction.

 

 

4. Boxer’s fracture:

  • Fracture through the neck of 5th metacarpal.
  • More common in boxers.

choices.text: Positive feedback
Negative feedback
Adaptive control regulation

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

 

Explanation

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels

 

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Fig: Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism

 

Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves →nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla→ release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feedforward: Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.

 

Option D. Adaptive control regulation: Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle

 

HAGLUND DEFORMITY

 

  • Haglund deformity is prominent Calcaneal tuberosity and overlying bursitis (retro-calcaneal).
  • It is a bony enlargement formed at posterosuperior aspect of calcaneum along with retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

choices.text: Anterior dislocation of hip
Posterior dislocation of hip
Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur
Fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A patient fell down riding a bicycle. He started having pain around hip. There was shortening of limb, and the attitude of limb was Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • Dashboard injury: occur with axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction - seen as one sits in the front seat of the car.
       
  • The typical attitude of the lower limb would be a flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR).

 

 

  • Complications: AVN of femoral head, sciatic nerve injury, associated fractures of femoral head and acetabulum and also associated knee injuries.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • CT scan is the best investigation to judge dislocation.
     
  • Treatment:
    • More the deformity is a sign that probably there is no associated fracture of acetabulum or femoral head/neck. These cases can undergo closed reduction under some sedation.
    • Reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Anterior Dislocation of Hip. It is less common than posterior dislocation. It is of 2 types. Type I: Pubic (femoral head lies superiorly) and Type II: Obturator (femoral head lies inferiorly). Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture (FABER) at the affected hip, with restriction of movement. Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type). Dislocation is usually seen on AP view. Treatment is reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

 

 

Option C. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur. The patients suffering from intertrochanteric femoral fractures are mainly of elder age group (> 60 years of age) with poor health condition & comorbidities. It is seen more commonly in males. The patient presents with severe pain, swelling & ecchymosis. There is tenderness present over the greater trochanter. The hip is externally rotated to > 45° (lateral border of foot touches the couch). There is > 1 inch of shortening in the affected limb. Broadening of greater trochanter is seen. The patient is unable to walk and SLR is also not possible.

 

 

Option D. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. They are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. Non-operative management for these fractures is rarely the treatment course. Young patients with femoral neck fractures will require treatment with emergent open reduction internal fixation. Non-displaced fractures are treated typically with percutaneous cannulated screws or a sliding hip screw. With displaced fractures in less active elderly patients, the treatment is given by hemiarthroplasty and with more active individuals, total hip arthroplasty is done.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The limb position of flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR) is specific of posterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: The following sets of X-rays are suggestive of:(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity.
    • Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur.
    • Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
    • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
       
  • Spine radiograph:
    • Loss of lumbar lordosis (Straightening).
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.
    • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
    • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
    • Erosions of anterior corners of vertebral body causing squaring of vertebral body.
    • Bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) with vertical orientation bridging vertebral bodies are seen. Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. It is the osteoclast that appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity. Long bone X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen. Skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Vertebral cortical thickening at superior and inferior end plates creates a picture frame vertebrae and diffuse sclerosis causing ivory vertebrae. Pelvic radiograph shows sclerotic iliopectineal line (Brim sign), fusion or disruption of sacroiliac joints, etc.

 

 

Blade of grass appearance

 

 

 

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism maybe primary (due to adenoma or hyperplasia), secondary (due to persistent hypocalcemia) or tertiary (when secondary hyperplasia leads to autonomous overactivity). Parathyroid adenoma is most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. It presents with subperiosteal resorption, and replacement of endosteal cavitation marrow by vascular granulation and fibrous tissue (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect. Clinical features are Abdominal groans (dyspepsia), psychic moans, renal stones and weak bones (Groans, moans, stones and Bones). Hyperparathyroidism causes diffuse rarefaction of bone (osteopenia) and osteitis fibrosa cystica. Radiological Features includes subperiosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis, loss of lamina dura (i.e. thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as thin white line, is resorbed), irregular, diffuse rarefaction of bones, i.e. generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull.

 

 

 

Resorption of lamina dura

 

 

Salt-pepper skull

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The radiographic images given the question shows:

 

A. Bamboo spine

 

B. Sacroiliitis

 

C. Loss of lumbar lordosis

 

D. Dagger’s sign

 

These features are characteristic of Ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A female present with pain and swelling over multiple peripheral small joints and deformity as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

  • The image shows swan neck deformity seen in RA.
  • Characteristic Deformities of Hand and Foot In RA:

 

 

 

 

Finger deformities in RA

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand. Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.

 

 

Option D. Scleroderma. Scleroderma is a severe CTD characterized by vascular, immune and fibrotic changes in the skin and internal organs. While tethering of the skin is the clinical hallmark of SSc, many patients develop musculoskeletal symptoms also. Manifestations may include rheumatic complaints ranging from arthralgias to frank arthritis, contractures and tendon friction rubs. Articular involvement contributes to disability and impaired quality of life. All joints may be affected, although the fingers (in particular the MCP and PIP joints), wrists and ankles predominate. As the disease progresses, there is tethering and contracture of the joints with impairment of movement and function.

 

 

Calcinosis and contracture of joints

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows swan neck deformity, which is characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: X-ray of an athlete shown in the image below. How is this fracture managed? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

 

Explanation:
 

The X-ray depicts a displaced transverse fracture of the patella. The appropriate treatment for this type of fracture is tension band wiring. This method stabilizes the fracture by converting tensile forces into compressive forces at the fracture site, promoting healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression plating - Typically used for long bone fractures and may not be ideal for patella fractures due to the specific biomechanics involved.

 

Option C. Internal fixation - A broad term that includes various methods such as screws, plates, and rods; however, for patellar fractures, tension band wiring is more specific and effective.

 

Option D. K-wire fixation - While K-wires are used in the tension band wiring technique, they are not used alone for optimal stabilization of transverse patellar fractures.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Tension band wiring is the recommended method for managing displaced transverse fractures of the patella, converting tensile forces into compressive forces to facilitate healing.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

 

  • The images show the cervical vertebrae where, at the lower cervical spine (C4-C7), there is an anterior slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. 
  • In the left image, C5 appears to be shifted anteriorly relative to C6. 
  • This slippage is referred to as spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis involves forward displacement of one vertebra over another.
  • Pathology:
    • The pars interarticularis is disrupted on both sides (spondylolysis), separating the posterior neural arch from vertebral body; gap is later filled by fibrous tissue.
    • The vertebral body undergoes anterior dislocation under stress.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Lateral view: Forward shift of the upper part of spinal column on the stable vertebra below; elongation of the arch or defective facets may be seen.
    • Oblique views are needed to clearly demonstrate fracture of pars interarticularis (Beheaded Scottie dog sign)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.
