questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE

 

  • The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex, is called Galeazzi Fracture-dislocation.
  • It is the fracture of necessity.
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.
  • Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: Definition of PUO includes all of the following except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Undiagnosed after one week of investigation

 

The correct answer is C because the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) does not specify that the fever must remain undiagnosed for only one week. According to the established criteria for diagnosing PUO, the investigation can be longer and more thorough before labeling a fever as PUO. The criteria include a fever exceeding 38.3°C on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain after comprehensive history taking, physical examinations, and routine investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks: This is incorrect because it is a part of the definition of PUO, where the fever must last for more than three weeks.

 

Option B. Immunocompromised status should be ruled out: This is incorrect  as a choice because being non-immunocompromised is a criterion in the diagnosis of PUO, which means any immunocompromised status should indeed be ruled out.

 

Option D. Temperature more than 38.3°C: This is also incorrect as it is part of the criteria, where the temperature must be more than 38.3°C on multiple occasions to consider it as PUO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Criteria for diagnosis of PUO:

 

  • Fever > 38.3 degrees C (101° F) on 2 occasions.
  • Duration > 3 weeks.
  • Not immunocompromised state.
  • Diagnosis not certain after history, physical examination and routine and obligatory investigations.

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray shown below. Identify the likely cause:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital

 

Explanation:

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)

 

CONGENITAL SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Congenital scoliosis is the most frequent congenital deformity of the spine.
  • Congenital curvatures are due to anomalous development of the vertebrae (failure of formation and/or segmentation).
  • In most cases, congenital scolioses are non-hereditary.
  • It is believed to be related to an insult to the fetus during spine embryological development (between the 5th-8th week of gestation).
  • 25% of curves are non-progressive, 25% mildly progressive and 50% highly progressive and will require treatment.
  • The mainstay of treatment is either observation or surgery.
  • The rigidity of the curve is assessed, and the rib hump measured.
  • Associated malformations must be looked for clinically: look for foot or leg asymmetry, craniofacial malformation, a Klippel-Feil web neck, and cardiac and urinary malformations.
  • Full-body-width Postero-anterior (PA) and lateral X-rays are essential.
  • After 1 year of age, X-rays should be taken standing, with the legs in extension and the pelvis level, to compensate for any leg length discrepancy.
  • The Cobb angle will be measured.
  • CT scans shows a bony bar.
  • Congenital scoliosis can be classified into defect of formation or defect of segmentation:
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra (two growth plates) with a contralateral bar
    • Unilateral unsegmented bar
    • Two consecutives fully segmented hemivertebrae
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra
    • Semi segmented hemivertebra
    • Wedge vertebra (partial failure of formation)
    • Incarcerated hemivertebra (smaller and induce little deformity as the hemivertebra sits in a non-growing block; the alignment of the pedicles usually remains straight)

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment consists of either observation of the curve or surgery, or, rarely, bracing.
    • Observation should be applied only for non-progressive curves with a balanced spine.
    • Bracing is inefficient in congenital scoliosis. It may be indicated for long flexible curves or to control the compensatory lumbar curve or help rebalancing the spine, or it may be used after an operation, for instance, until the fusion is solid.
    • Surgery is the mainstay of care.
    • Prophylactic surgery:  surgery that will prevent further worsening or allow progressive correction over time. These operations are in situ fusion and hemi epiphysiodesis.
    • In situ fusion can be done with a single posterior fusion, with or without instrumentation or with an anterior fusion, or a 360° fusion.

 

 

  • Hemiepiphysiodesis tends to achieve progressive correction over time, taking advantage of the intact growth plates on the concave side of the deformity.  It has to be done ideally before the age of 5 to take advantage of the growth potential of the spine to allow a progressive correction of the deformity. It should not be carried out if there is a kyphosis component to the deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic. Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial. It is grouped by age. In children age 3 and younger, it is called infantile scoliosis. In age 4-10, it is called juvenile scoliosis. In age >10, it is called adolescent scoliosis. Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending (Adams test) as opposed to postural scoliosis. Compensatory curve due to limb length discrepancy or sciatic list (due to disc prolapsed) disappear on sitting.  Postural scoliosis disappears on forward bending.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular. This type is caused by a nervous system problem such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and polio. It may present at any age; and in many cases progresses relentlessly, particularly in patients with more severe neurologic and systemic involvement. Progressive deformity may limit mobility and seating status, and may be associated with primary or secondary effects on cardiopulmonary function over time. Management includes observation, non-operative interventions such as bracing, specialized seating systems, and surgery.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis. It is hereditary, hamartomatous disorder, that affects central and peripheral nervous system, skeletal, skin and deeper soft tissue. It is one of the commonest single gene disorder affecting the skeletal system. Clinical presentation includes-cafe au lait spots (most common feature) axillary, and inguinal freckling (2nd m.c), cutaneous neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas (~5% are premalignant), Lisch nodule on iris, veruccous hyperplasia (thickened overgrown valvety soft skin), elephantiasis (pachy- dermatocele), optic glioma, skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, hemihypertrophy) and cognitive deficits (learning disability).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows hemivertebra and block vertebra, which are characteristic of congenital type of scoliosis.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tuberculoma

 

Explanation:

 

The MRI findings of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in conjunction with a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy are characteristic of tuberculoma. Tuberculomas are focal infections that typically present as ring-enhancing lesions in the brain, often around the brainstem, and can conglomerate. The lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy is indicative of necrosis, which is a feature seen in tuberculomas (and also in conditions like toxoplasmosis). The combination of imaging and spectroscopy findings helps distinguish tuberculomas from other similar conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurocysticercosis (NCC): Typically presents with cystic lesions in the brain, which may show ring enhancement but does not characteristically show a lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.

 

Option C. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML): Generally shows non-enhancing, white matter lesions on MRI without a significant lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: These fungal infections might present similarly on imaging but do not typically show a lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculomas: 

 

  • Tuberculomas- foci of infection and show ring enhancing lesion
  • More common around brainstem
  • Show conglomeration
  • MR spectroscopy shows lipid lactate peak – necrosis (also seen in toxoplasmosis)

 

No prominent metabolite is seen in NCC/PML/Cryptococcoses.

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology 
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. CBNAAT: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. TB: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: HLA B27 is associated in 90% cases
It is non-erosive and only joints are affected
Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign
Affects males more than females

questions.text: All are true about Ankylosing spondylitis except:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is non-erosive and only joints are affected

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by erosive changes.  
  • AS is not completely non-erosive.
  • Over time, inflammation can lead to erosive changes, especially in the sacroiliac joints and the spine.
  • The inflammatory process in AS often leads to erosion of the vertebrae and the formation of syndesmophyte (bone spurs), which contribute to the fusion of spinal segments.
  • While AS primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), it can also involve other structures.
  • Extra-articular manifestations can include enthesitis (inflammation of the sites where tendons and ligaments attach to bone), uveitis (eye inflammation), and in some cases, systemic symptoms like fatigue and anemia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HLA-B27 is associated in 90% of cases: HLA-B27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Approximately 90% of patients with ankylosing spondylitis test positive for the HLA-B27 antigen. However, not all individuals with this antigen will develop the disease, and not all AS patients will test positive for HLA-B27. The exact role of HLA-B27 in the pathogenesis of AS is not fully understood, but it is considered a significant genetic risk factor. HLA-B27 positivity is used as part of the diagnostic process and can help in predicting the likelihood of AS in patients with symptoms.

 

Option C. Involvement of sacroiliac joint is earliest sign: Sacroiliac joint involvement is often one of the earliest signs of ankylosing spondylitis. The sacroiliac joints are typically among the first to be affected in AS. Early symptoms include lower back pain and stiffness that improves with activity and worsens with rest. X-rays or MRI of the sacroiliac joints can reveal characteristic changes associated with AS, such as sacroiliitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joints) and eventually, structural changes such as joint fusion.

 

 

Option D. Affects males more than females: Ankylosing spondylitis is more common in males than females. Studies suggest that the male-to-female ratio for AS is approximately 2:1 to 3:1. The disease may present differently in women, sometimes leading to a delay in diagnosis. Women with AS might have a less pronounced spinal involvement and more peripheral joint symptoms compared to men.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis is an erosive inflammatory condition in which axial skeleton particularly in the spine and sacroiliac joints and other organs are affected.

questions.text: What is the management of choice for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coiling

 

The management of choice for aneurysms by interventional radiologists is coiling. This minimally invasive procedure involves the insertion of platinum coils into the aneurysm through an endovascular route. The coils promote clotting within the aneurysm, effectively reducing the risk of rupture and stabilizing the aneurysm.

 

Coiling is performed under the guidance of digital subtraction angiography (DSA), which allows the radiologist to visualize the blood vessels and accurately place the coils within the aneurysm. This technique has become the gold standard for treating cerebral aneurysms due to its minimally invasive nature and high success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clipping: This is a surgical procedure where a neurosurgeon places a clip at the neck of the aneurysm to prevent blood flow into it. While effective, it is more invasive than coiling and typically not performed by interventional radiologists.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). It is not a treatment for aneurysms but a supportive therapy to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Angioplasty: Angioplasty is used to widen narrowed or obstructed blood vessels, often in cases of peripheral arterial disease. It is not a primary treatment for aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coiling is the preferred management for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists, involving the insertion of coils to promote clotting and stabilize the aneurysm.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), also known as Graves' orbitopathy, is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals. TED is an autoimmune condition associated with thyroid dysfunction, typically hyperthyroidism. The disease leads to inflammation and swelling of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, causing the eyes to bulge outward (proptosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital varix: Orbital varices are venous malformations that can cause intermittent proptosis, but they are not the most common cause. They typically become symptomatic during activities that increase venous pressure, such as straining or bending over.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant intraocular tumor that primarily affects children. It is not a common cause of proptosis in middle-aged adults.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors and the most common orbital tumor in adults, but they are not the most frequent cause of proptosis. These tumors tend to grow slowly and cause progressive proptosis.

 

Intraocular tumours

Most common in adults : Melanoma

Most common in children : Retinoblastoma

 

Intraorbital tumours

Most common in adults : Hemangioma

Most common in children : Rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is thyroid eye disease (TED), a condition related to thyroid dysfunction that leads to inflammation and swelling within the orbit.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option
